description: From Middle English glew, glue, from Old French glu (“glue, birdlime”), from Late Latin glūs (stem glūt-), from Latin glūten. Related to clay.
Displaced native Old English līm (“glue”) and ġelīman (“to glue”).

entries.meaning: A hard gelatin made by boiling bones and hides, used in solution as an adhesive; or any sticky adhesive substance.
(figurative) Anything that binds two things or people together.

verbs.description: glue (third-person singular simple present glues, present participle gluing or glueing, simple past and past participle glued)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To join or attach something using glue.
examples: I need to glue the chair-leg back into place.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause something to adhere closely to; to follow attentively.
examples: His eyes were glued to the screen.
